issues.description: Class naming and concrete implementations in the solution repository deviate from the UML/problem specification: the problem statement and template expect classes named Seal, Pig, and Goat (and examples in Main use these names). The solution repository does not provide implementations for Seal, Pig, and Goat; instead it provides SpaceSeal, SpacePig, and SpaceGoat. This mismatch changes the effective class names (and thus the output of getClass().getSimpleName()), and also causes the message strings produced by the provided implementations to include the unexpected "Space" prefix (e.g. "SpaceGoat Buttinsky is milked" instead of the expected "Goat Buttinsky is milked"). This discrepancy will confuse students comparing the reference solution with the UML and template, and may cause tests or instructor expectations that refer to Goat/Pig/Seal to fail or seem inconsistent.
issues.suggested_fix:
Align the solution repository with the UML/problem statement by providing concrete classes named Goat, Pig, and Seal that implement the required interfaces and behavior. Either:
- Rename SpaceGoat, SpacePig, and SpaceSeal to Goat, Pig, and Seal (and update their constructors/messages if necessary), or
- Add wrapper classes Goat, Pig, and Seal that delegate to the existing Space* implementations (so the class names and message text match the specification). Ensure messageOnMilk() and messageOnRide() produce strings using the expected animal type name (e.g. "Goat [name] is milked" and "Riding on Goat [name]") — or rely on getClass().getSimpleName() in runtime outputs so the names match the UML/example. This will remove the naming/output discrepancy and prevent confusion when students compare template, UML, and the reference solution.

issues.description: The problem statement and template expect concrete animal classes named Goat, Pig, and Seal (students are explicitly instructed to implement Goat, Pig, Seal and the template's Main uses these names). The solution repository, however, provides concrete implementations named SpaceGoat, SpacePig, and SpaceSeal instead of Goat, Pig, and Seal. This creates an unexpected identifier mismatch: students reading the problem/template will look for Goat/Pig/Seal classes, but the provided solution uses different class names, breaking the direct name-to-concept mapping and causing confusion about which classes satisfy the requirements.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the concrete animal class names consistent across artifacts. Either rename the solution classes to Goat, Pig, and Seal (e.g., SpaceGoat -> Goat, SpacePig -> Pig, SpaceSeal -> Seal) so they match the problem statement and template, or (if the 'Space' prefix is intentional) update the problem statement and template to refer to SpaceGoat/SpacePig/SpaceSeal. Prefer renaming the solution classes to Goat/Pig/Seal to preserve the exercise wording and avoid extra cognitive load for students.
